string-array.item: The android debug bridge, it essentially provides a bridge to the android device. It has various features that involve interacting with the current android device. We used it to install our apk file via \'adb install path/to/apk.apk\', this put our built android application onto the virtual device so we could test our app. We also used it to connect to the android virtual device via \'adb shell\' this let us access the filesystem of the virtual device allowing us to view the filesystem and remove files.

The emulator command allowed us to start the virtual devices via \'emulator -avd avdname\' emulator also allows us to change many aspects of the emulator such as debugging options, audio options, networking options, ui options and more. It is basically a way to start virtual devices and customize many aspects about them.

The android command provides a way to list your current android virtual devices(\'android list avd\') and also create new ones(\'android create avd -n [name] -t [targetid]\') Also if you need to you can also move update and delete AVDs. It provides everything you need for managing your virtual devices.

The screenshot2 command lets you take a snapshot of the current virtual device \'screenshot2 -e lab01.png\', \'-e\' specifies that you want to capture the first emulator. It is pretty simple and only has a couple more options including \'-d\' which captures the first android device, \'-s\' allows you to specify a serial number, and \'-l\' which captures the snapshot in landscape mode

Gradle is a very important command, it builds your app. If you have a build.gradle file in your project directory and run \'gradle build\', assuming the app has no errors, it will create a huge build directory which includes your .apk file which is what is run on the android device.

Lint allows for analysis of your source code and outputting it in a .xml(\'lint --xml [output.xml] [projectdir]\') or .html(\'lint --html [output.html] [projectdir]\') file. It reports errors and warnings about your source code clearly and also allowing for some customization of what errors are shown or not such as \'-w\' which ignores warnings and only looks for errors
A project is your whole project which contains everything required for your app to successfully build.
A panel is a section that can provide information or tools that can be opened by clicking it.
A toolbar is a list of shortcuts which allow you to open various things or preform tasks, it is also customizable allowing you to add or remove shortcuts.
A status bar displays notifications about updates and information like the android studio version.
The preview pane should show your android device and what the layout will currently look like, it also has various options to customize the preview device.
The android pane has options to interact with your current running virtual device such as screenshots, recordings, log info and more.
The project explorer allows you to view your source tree as a hierarchy and open files from there.
The .idea folder stores many xml files which contain information about the project for example gradle settings, module settings version control settings and more.
Intellisense will provide a list of valid completions to your code in order to speed up your coding process and help you keep track of valid keywords.
modules make up a project, example a module contains the source code and app resources.
Live layout is a preview of what your app layout will look on the screen and it changes as you code.
git init will create an empty git repository.
git commit will record and save any changes to the repository.
git push will update your remote repository on github and your local repository.
git add will add contents to your index.
git pull will fetch contents from another repository and merge with your project.
git branch will allow you list, create or delete branches.
git clone will allow you to copy a repository into a new local directory.
